text: hi everyone combination war and pandemic
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of this new
beach house album once twice melody this
i believe is the eighth full-length lp
from the legendary baltimore dream pop
duo beach house alex scally and victoria
legrand are back with what is
pretty much their biggest offering yet
in terms of size and instrumentation too
this thing is an 80 minute project with
four chapters or sides to it which
average out to about 20 minutes each and
as a long time beach house listener it's
my expert assessment that this is their
most aesthetically diverse project since
2010's teen dream all of the drum
machines and sequence drums live
drumming on this project plus the
countless synth patches across this
thing from ethereal chords to very
analog and kind of old-school bubbly
arpeggios strings electric guitars
acoustic guitars lots of vocal effects
on some of these cuts too beach house is
nothing if not consistent and with fan
favorites such as their self-titled and
devotion from back in the day they
forged a super distinct sound that since
then they have stuck very closely to but
there are also moments in the duo's
catalog where they experiment
instrumentally a fair bit and in a lot
of ways i think once twice melody
continues on that path as well but just
on a grander scale there are some spots
on this lp where i think some of the
experiments don't quite pan out like the
vocoder vocals on runaway which i'm
still not all that crazy about as well
as the cycling vocal samples of don't
don't don't
down down on the track only you know
which i i think i have warmed up a
little bit too but really the star of
the show on this song for me is that
huge thick shoegazy rush of synths and
guitars that are just so heavy and
crushing and visceral meanwhile the song
illusion forever sounds like an
experiment in seeing how far you can
push reverb without it completely
destroying the song itself which for
beach house is saying something the
sheen and atmosphere on this track is so
full it's so heavy it's so bright it
sounds the way i imagine
being a vampire blasted with
all these rays of sunlight must feel
which does distract from the song a
little bit in my opinion but i i will
say there's nothing else on the record
as enveloping as this there are also a
few moments on this lp that i think are
maybe a little too typical for beach
house at this point through me for
example does have some lovely moments in
its run time but the airy synth chords
and hypnotic arpeggios sound almost
plain and average in comparison with
everything else it shares space with in
the first chapter plus that floor tom b
in the lightly droning guitars in the
background are a little mind numbing i
think they make for some of the weaker
and muddier crescendos on this lp many
nights is almost like an ambient pop
lullaby that i think instrumentally
could have used a bit more variation and
hurts to love while this track does have
some of the more endearing lyrics on the
lp singing about uh wanting to love past
pain and bad experiences and traumas and
hurt the synth and sequence drum combo
on this one feels almost like a devotion
throwback but there's something about it
that doesn't really have that same kind
of magic simplicity could be the subtly
psychedelic effects could be the uh
uptick in tempo so with a few
reservations being stated there i will
say the rest of this tracklist
is pretty great there is a whole lot of
fire on this record like the stunning
instrumental display showcased on the
opening title track the acoustic guitar
strings and marching drum combo are
fantastic the eerie little vocal
harmonies from victoria buried their way
into my head on first listen once twice
melody
and the way the synth arpeggios take
over in the second half and move things
almost into a prague synth dream pop
blend is kind of incredible superstar
there is something in my opinion that's
very therapeutic about the bareness of
this track and the throbbing electronics
victoria's calm and steady lead vocal
builds the song up into
man just a a layer upon layer upon layer
of synthesizers and electronics that are
just so dense and so fused together i i
can't even tell you what's going on i
can't even separate it from itself to
pick out each individual sound like am i
hearing a bunch of synth layers here am
i hearing a [ __ ] supernova could be
either then there's pink funeral why is
this one so creepy this is legitimately
the creepiest beach house song ever blue
skies turned black behind our back once
was a fairy tale
then it all went to hell with the heavy
drums and the dark organ chords this
thing is a dream pop death esp meanwhile
has one of the weirdest and most surreal
instrumental palettes on the entire lp
it's like each individual sound isn't
existing on the same plane as everything
else from the acoustic guitar to the
lo-fi blasted out but very quiet drum
loops spectral background vocals watery
lead melodies of victoria's vocals
sounding uh very just toned down and
somber through the whole thing again
it's really surreal how it all comes
together and this is i imagine how
my brain might make up instrumentation
in my head while i'm sleeping then
there's new romance which might be my
favorite cut on the second chapter the
instrumental layering on this one is so
dense and full and orgasmic the song has
this perfect cut-off ending i'm not
usually a big fan of cut off endings but
it just kind of suddenly ends at a point
that feels like i'm just being blasted
with this beautiful rush of
instrumentation and the moment it
disappears all i'm left with is like
that ecstasy of everything that it was
like kind of bringing to me up until
that moment the lyrics on the track
paint a picture of an exciting new love
uh victoria saying last night i'm
messing up now i feel like dressing up
is one of the catchiest and funniest or
friends i think she's put together then
the final moment in chapter two over and
over is the longest cut on this entire
lp stands at seven minutes and the rush
of all of these synth chords the chord
changes that accompany the hook it's one
of the most just gorgeous on impact
moments in beach house's whole catalog
and after the midpoint the song just
launches into this huge
explorative synth odyssey that i get
lost in every time with the song sunset
beach house kills it on an acoustic
ballad with
chords that i could hear tom petty
crooning over but instead victoria sings
on top of it like she is a chorus of
ghost children from the turn of the
century which i mean in the most
positive way possible yeah it's just a
very beautiful piece of string kissed
folk the song another go around runs
like a whisper quiet inner monologue
from victoria and the more simple
approach on the instrumentation allows
the lyrics to really hit describing what
feels like this
cycle of i guess short-lived romantic
interests that are there when the one
that you need isn't as victoria says in
the song there's also masquerade which
is another cut with a lot of throbbing
electronics on it some might read it as
being a bit of an 80s thing but it kind
of feels like a dead ringer to an extent
for uh the knife or even like some fever
ray so in a way it may be a little too
derivative but the gothic bells go
absolutely hard as do the spine tingling
whispers that victoria delivers on the
hook and that here tonight gone forever
refrain in the final moments of the song
still haunts me look i could keep going
through all of these songs individually
but just to put it straight forward
there's a lot of highlights on this
thing there's a lot of fire in the track
list the biggest issue with this thing
is really that it's not just an
80-minute album but it really
feels like an 80-minute album maybe
because that trademark beach house
pacing isn't really doing it any favors
because while this thing is beautiful
and does contain some of my favorite
beach house material to date uh it is
not a breeze it is not a breeze at all
the record is sectioned out into a
double album format a four chapter
format i encourage fans and listeners to
approach this thing in whatever way they
feel comfortable with because at least
in my opinion
sitting down and listening to all of it
in one go the flow doesn't exactly
reward that type of listening experience
i think as i listen to this project
again and again there doesn't seem to be
any kind of guiding aesthetics or sonics
to each chapter as well and i think
that's led to a record where the 18
tracks here stand stronger on their
individual merits than they do a whole
ass 80-minute record now recently when i
had a conversation with alex and
victoria in an interview about this
record they told me they made it pretty
clear that they broke a sweat over the
sequencing of this project but i i
really don't hear it which is weird
because the massive amount of work
they've put into everything else like
shows instantaneously so even though i
have a massive amount of love for a lot
of these tracks they just kind of run
together like a compilation
more than an album i feel as if i could
just put this record on shuffle and get
mostly the same vibe out of listening to
the whole thing
i'll even go as far as to say the
closing track modern love stories brings
absolutely nothing to the table as a
finisher like it's not the grand ending
that i think it was shooting for which
impossible task given just how huge
everything else on the record is which
you know while it is an issue i don't
think it's the worst issue a project can
have i'm still massively impressed with
the vast vast vast majority of the songs
and the records runtime in general and i
still think it's exciting to hear the
duo experimenting and trying new things
after all these years yeah while it's
not the most cleanly groomed and cut and
dry beach house record the duo has ever
done it's still one of their boldest
albums ever has some of their best
material ever i guess the biggest
argument against it is that they let
their ambitions get the better of them
ever so slightly feeling a light to
decent eight on this one tran position
